awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: GEM: Understanding Connections between Earth’s Magnetotail and Ionosphere through Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling is the process connecting hot, low density plasma in the magnetosphere with the cold, high density plasma in the ionosphere. This coupling is especially important during geomagnetic storms and substorms when increasing currents in the magnetosphere close through the ionosphere, resulting in increased outflow of ionospheric plasma into the magnetosphere and increased precipitation of energized magnetospheric plasma into the ionosphere. This process, important to understanding space weather impacts, will be studied with a combination of space-based observations and ground-based auroral imagers and the NSF-supported Poker Flat meridian spectrograph. The project supports research of a graduate student from a member of an underrepresented group in STEM and three women in early career stages.

Coupling between the Earth’s ionosphere and magnetosphere is a critical component of the dynamics that occur during storms and substorms. To improve understanding of the connections between phenomena in the magnetotail and in the ionosphere, the research will combine global imaging of the magnetosphere using energetic neutral atoms with auroral imaging of the ionosphere. These techniques will be supported by in situ measurements and global modeling. Case studies of particular active intervals will be used as well as statistical studies that include superposed epoch analyses. The following science questions will be addressed: (1) Under what conditions do we observe both energized ions in the magnetotail and auroral enhancements? (2) What is the temporal relationship between ion energization in the magnetotail and auroral enhancements? (3) What is the spatial relationship between mesoscale regions of energized ions in the magnetotail and auroral enhancements?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award provided the mean of collaboration between the University of New Hampshire and Eastern Michigan University (a primarily undergraduate institution). This award has provided a unique research experience. The collaboration provided opportunities for undergraduate students, graduate students, and junior faculty members from both universities to complete research in the field of Magnetospheric Physics. All students were able to collaborate in an advanced research experience including data acquisition, computational mathematics, data analysis, research presentations, and the writing process.

 

We applied statistical analysis techniques as well as case studies of several geomagnetic storms to examine the global response of the geospace system, from the plasma sheet in the magnetotail to the ground. Students were involved in every step of the process. This involvement developed their skills in mathematics, physics, computer science, the research process, presentation, and writing.

Using statistical results, model results, and case studies we verified agreement of general trends in the plasma sheet during different types of geomagnetic activity. Students participated in the developed of an automated detection algorithm for mesoscale heated regions in TWINS ion temperature maps. Theses automated results were then used in conglomeration with solar wind measurements, in situ inner magnetospheric plasma measurements, and ground-based magnetometers to track the movement of high energy plasma throughout the Dungey Cycle for case study events. We applied advanced statistical methods ranging from superposed epoch analysis to network analysis based on time lag correlation matrices to examine the relationship between the different data. We compared results to different models including Open Geospace General Circulation Model (Open GGCM). We observed spatial and temporal signatures of the plasma sheet’s response to different types of solar wind driven events. We also examined the statistics of Flow Channels Observed as Regions of Ion Heating in Energetic Neutral Atom Images.
